When I walked out, there was 2 tables on patio that she could have given us!!!! BAD attitude, and bad customer service!! We went across the street to eat instead
author: Coco L.

description:
Gosh, if the service wasn't so slow there would have been 4 stars.  Me and my friend stopped in for happy hour after work.  We wanted to grab a couple martinis and something to snack on.  It was a beautiful evening and we sat on the large patio under a heat lamp.  There were lots of people out but the place wasn't packed by any means.

We ordered two martinis and a small pizza.  The pizza came out in 2 minutes.. unfortunately it was taken away 5 minutes later because it was supposed to go to a different table.  We didn't care; it was sort of funny.  But it took at least 15-20 minutes to get our first drink.  Geesh.. it sucks sitting around sober waiting for a happy hour cocktail.  And I don't understand because it appeared most people were just drinking beer and wine.  It wasn't like everyone was ordering pina coladas and frozen margaritas!

On the plus side, the drinks were super tasty, even though they were a bit on the small side.  The pizza was super tasty too with a great crisp crust.  Even cashing out took 20 minutes to get change.  Hello!  Please make happy hour HAPPY!  Get more staff because your customers are thirst!
author: Philip D.

description:
This rating is solely based on cocktails!

Skip the food and head straight for an extra dirty martini. Holy deliciousness. One of the unexpectedly best dirties I have had in the city so far!
author: Heidi K.

description:
Once again, another place I would not go to during the Giants season, but otherwise, probably.  It is a very cute restaurant, gotta love the heart shaped martini olive...  Well this place is just full of funny memories.  There was a large party of us, all seated outside, and everyone (except myself) proceeded to get drunk.  And I mean drunk drunk.  Not tipsy, not buzzed, but DRUNK.  It was fabulous.  The server was an absolute sweetheart, and went along with all the drunk jokes, all the gross jokes, and she was given a hefty enough tip for it.  I wouldn't go so far as to say the food is great, but it's food.  It's ok.  The same you would get at any other restaurant in San Fran, but slightly overpriced.  

After dinner, the rest of my party proceeded to run around the street trying to find a cab...and all 6 of us crammed into one...that was comfy.  Shotgun!
author: Marley E.

description: The food was acceptable, the service was decent and the atmosphere was exactly what you would expect.  But this place has the audacidty to place a line item percentage charge for health care for thier employees on your bill.  They are so angry about having to provide basic health care for thier empoyees that they publically protest on every bill and make sure you know they are passing the entire cost onto you as thier customer.  I refuse to give my money to a company that is this morally bankrupt!
author: Samuel C.

description:
A former business associate took me to lunch here out of the sheer kindness of his heart, and I repayed the favor by making him watch me devour the biggest, messiest hamburger ever consumed by mankind.

I ordered it "medium", but they served it up rare and bloody. No matter, I took on the challenge wholeheartedly. At its core was a mound of ground beef and a slice of sharp cheddar, both crammed into a sourdough bun. To this I added tomatoes, onions, pickle slices, avocado, lettuce, ketchup, mustard, and mayo. The result: a single, heart clogging, mouth watering meal, a meal that only the great Kobayashi could conquer. But what one man can do, another can do. And I attacked this beast of burgers with great ferocity, as if life itself depended on the completion of this single feat.

A look of horror came across David's face as I mauled my prey, food all over my face, meat juices dripping down my hands. People at other tables began to point and scoff in disbelief, while others looked away in disgust. Mothers covered their children's eyes, to protect these innocents from the horrible, harsh realities of life.

Darkness warshed over the Dude...

After completing my near-fatal mission, I leaned back, loosened my belt, and reveled in my triumph...in my victory of man over beast. I had stared death in the eye, and I lived to tell the tale.

Sorry, David. Thanks for lunch though.
author: Wes F.

description:
I'm actually pretty shocked to see such negative reviews.

I've been to Momos many times and have never been disappointed. It is fun on a game day when the crazy fans are out (I'm one of them)... It is delicious on the days the parents want to buy dinner or lunch... and it is absolutely a great place to have a cocktail.

The outdoor seating is the best, but if you want it to be a little more intimate and quiet, the dinning room is best.

Enjoy!
author: Dee C.

description: Service started really, really slow and we were ready to leave when the waitress showed up and apologized. After that it was fine and they were cheerful. The food was okay and we had the calamari (hard to mess up) and the heirloom tomatoes which were a level C not an overly large serving or super- flavorful (sweet). Obliviously the location can't be beat as we were there for a baseball game.
author: Woody H.

description:
If you pop your collar or carry a tiny dog stuffed in your purse, this is your place. I've been here a few times (second time wasn't by choice). The two times I've been here were before as well as after a Giants game. The location is perfect, but the customers and service blows. It's Douche Bag Central and High Maintenance Capital. I would much rather go a few blocks down to 21st Amendment Brewery. There you get service (upstairs) with no problem and the crowd is way better. 

I know the city is expensive and so I have no complaints for this place for being over priced. It's like that everywhere here. This place gets my one star for being over packed, having the attitude that they think they're the best, and crappy service.
author: CLINTON W.

description:
Ate at  MoMo's for the first time for dinner before attending Cirque du Soleil at ATT.

Brunch is much better.  My GF got there first and was seated at an unacceptable table and the hostess was very accommodating in seating us elsewhere.  The service was also pretty good.  Unfortunately, the dinner food didn't quite measure up.  Had gumbo with pot roast (the Blue Plate Special of the Night) and my GF had a 1/2 dozen oysters on the 1/2 shell and a crab salad.  The food was "ok" but I've definitely had better.  So, only 2 stars on the food but 3 stars overall.  

Don't think I'd come here for dinner again, but it still shines for brunch before a game which remains at 4 stars and an average of 3.5 but we can't give 1/2 stars.  So, it's 3 stars overall from me.
author: Martin C.

description:
MoMo's is a restaurant that benefits from the fact that it is right across the street from the San Francisco Giant's AT&T Park.

To tell you the truth, I have only been there a couple of times when a baseball game was not immanent or just finished.  

One game days, this is the place to be.  It is packed, pre-game with a nice mix of young sports fans and middle aged pre-game partiers.  Every Pre-game, they have two bar carts out on the patio, but if you are able to wrangle a patio table they still have waitresses that get to you every now and then to get you a fresh round of drinks.  The wait can be a bit though.  The prices are not the best, but are a little better than in the ballpark.  They switch from pint glasses to 12 oz. plastic cups on game days, a cup of Sierra Nevada, as I remember is $6.  

The place is just as crazy after the game as it is before.  But this is a place to be if you want to meet a player.  Not a too cool, I am god's gift to ladies type, but an actual SF giants team member.   Some of the players stop before they head home and  I have met a couple of notable Giants stars here.

Tip:  Get to know the Bouncers and Bartenders.  I was lucky enough to have an "in" by knowing a bartender outside of MoMo's before my game time frequency but even three years later, by asking folks their names once and remembering them I have gotten numerous comps and even have gotten to stay after closing.  

Overall, this is the place for pre-game drinks unless you have read any of my other reviews.
author: Ben A.

description:
Caveat: Our visits were more than 10 years ago on a nearly 2-week vacation and we don't recall the food. 

We had stayed at a hotel south of the city (Burlingame?)and would stop at MoMo's nightly (sometimes 2 hrs or more) before we caught the train that would take us near the hotel. It is one of our favorite and lasting memories. Great atmosphere, fun, good drinks but I don't recall the food. We'd definitely go back for a nightcaps. The servers and were friendly.
author: Tammie B.

description:
Horrible.

Could this be because I don't care for sports bars? Maybe.

Could it be because I don't care for muscle-y jocks who can't manage to stay out of my personal area? Possibly. 

Could it be because I don't like hanging out in places with a bunch of stupid drunk girls who talk in that whiny-slurry-drunky voice and also can't manage to keep their ass/huge handbag/elbows out of my face/ribs/back when it's not even that crowded? Perhaps.

Could it be because someone stole my cell phone from beside me? Likely.

Could it be because I called them ahead of time to find out if they were showing the De La Hoya/Mayweather fight, and they said YES, so I walked completely across town, bought two $7 dollar bottles of Corona, and the saddest $6 plate of soggy french fries I had ever eaten and then when it was getting a bit late, asked when the fight was to come on, and they  told me that they weren't showing it far too late for me to go somewhere else to watch it? Damn straight!

This place sucks!
author: Crystal R.

description: our office staff was at UCSF in the morning and decided to grab lunch at Momo's during the week (thankfully the Giants were out of town, so it wasn't crowded at all). the service wasn't that friendly, attentive or even quick for that matter as other places i've been to, but it wasn't completely bad either; just average i'd say. i kind of like the decor and atmosphere (feels kind of like a bistro, and we sat outside on the front patio), yet on the more upscale end of things in terms of price too. the food isn't outstanding nor bad; i'd say a tad above average here. their fries are really good...but i don't go to restaurants primarily for fries. i mean it's just an average place and probably not my first choice to go, but not a place i'd completely "veto" either. it's just "ehh...okay, i ate here."
author: Mike C.

description:
One star is for the closeness to my house (of which there are other places even closer that are even better), one star for the fact that I was there on a NON baseball game night, and the last star is for the French Onion Soup (which honestly is the only reason why anyone should go here).  

Heading down to Momo's on a NON-baseball night with some friends while wearing my ugg boots should in deed sum up the whole night (pretty UNinteresting).  My martini was week and the service was super slow.  The French Onion soup however... man... when I am craving some french onion soup I will make the unbelievable trek of two whole blocks down there for it because it was a mind blowing, tongue numbing, absolutely sensational experience that I would recommend to anyone.  Unfortunately however, I really don't like this place.  

On busy nights it is packed with drunken ballgame goers who are so obnoxiously drunk that they push and shove until you are asking yourself why it is again you stepped into such a god awful place.  Oh well.. it is what it is... and that would be the closest bar to the ball park.
author: Kylie L.

description:
This is an edit to what was previously a three-star review.

Although the Man and I had misgivings from over a year ago (bad treatment, bad service, the occasional sub-par meal), we hit up MoMo's again recently because we believe in billionth chances.  MoMo's only served to remind us why we don't go.  

No one stood behind the desk in the lobby and we had to play the eye-catching game with any MoMo's server who walked by (quite a few did before we were finally seated).  The waiter treated us awkwardly and the food took damn-near forever.  Dessert was bad (how is it possible to be out of creme brulee AND cookies?!!) and the wine was swill.

We flagged a passing server down twenty minutes after completing our meal in order to obtain the check (the waiter wouldn't meet eyes).  When the check arrived, it was hardly legible - striped with red and it wouldn't unroll.  Apparently it was the last piece of paper on its tape - which isn't necessarily a crime, but it was the straw the broke the camel's back.  

I'm done with MoMo's, man.

--------------

For your edification, here was my old 3-star review:

Meals are great but I'm not too big on gourmet hamburgers with peas.

Best feature: For dessert I can have a delicate creme brulee and my boyfriend can have a rich pair of chocolate-chip cookies.

Avoid going during baseball season, particularly on game days, unless you like a crowded and utterly abrasive atmosphere.
author: Angela N.

description:
I came to MoMo's with a buddy on a Saturday night around 6:30pm and this place was absolutely EMPTY. The only reason why we went in to try this place out was because you could see the hostess from outside and if boredom could have a face, it would be that of the hostess at MoMo's. So we felt bad for her and so we decided to give her some customers to host. 

We ate at the bar and we ordered the (1) sliders, (2) pepperoni pizza, & (3) shoestring onions. The sliders were decent, but honestly, I don't think they're worth $13.00. Each of three sliders were tiny (about 3 bites) and they were all lacking in taste. I didn't have the pepperoni pizza, but it looked pretty plain. The shoestring onions were a nice complement to the sliders, but it was just a huge pile of fried onion strings so nothing to really rave about. 

Our bill for two came out to a little over $60.00, which I felt was WAY too pricey for bar food and two drinks. I could've gotten better food for cheaper at Gordon Biersch or any pub around the corner. If I were to ever come back in the future, it would have to be during Happy Hour or something when the prices are a lot more reasonable.
author: Roy C.

description:
Someone tell me why anyone would pay their hard earned cash for the garbage they make here. ...

Was helping VM clean his boat across the street at South Beach Harbor...as we're driving by MoMo's we both realize we are hungry enough to eat my hand (I'd just slathered on white chocolate hand balm...mmMMm) and as we say this, i sight MoMo's patio area.  

It is like college frat/sorority party.  They've got the bbq, bar with tap beer, boys in backward caps, girls with their bf's sweatshirt.. feeling adventurous, we decided to eat at Mo's..

By the time we get back, the happy-hour and giant's lovers are staggering away, red faced and obnoxious.  wished they were staying then i would not have set foot in that glorified apple bee's..

The decor...suck
The food... sucked
The drink...omg...are you kidding me??? at least apple bees have 20 0z frozen daiquiris for $10

I ate asparagus & pepper appetizer and two martinis with 3 olives each...he had the baby back rib and one glass of tap beer...our total?
$78...go to denny's... go to tgif.... fuck go to your neighborhood Safeways frozen section ...but skip this joint..





.
author: Je C.

description:
If you charge $17 for a caesar salad in this economy it better be a damn good.  Unfortunately for both of us... It wasn't.

Decent spot for a drink before or after a baseball game, if you're looking for sunshine.  For lunch or dinner, you can do much better any just about any other restaurant in the area.
author: eric f.

description:
I have eaten bugs in Thailand, snake in Nepal, enormous bean burritos from taco trucks in the Mission and I have NEVER experienced the kind of stomach-aching, ass-exploding food sickness I have just been handed from Momo's. After eating there today at lunch, I'm not well.

Beware. You have been warned.
author: Eric ..

description:
This place looks like the kind of restaurant where your estranged father tries to bribe you to spend time with him by buying you a moderately expensive lunch.

I wasn't very inspired by the menu, but I'll admit that I wanted to try the chicken pot pie and the macaroni 'n' cheese (which looked damn tasty on my friend's plate, btw). I would have felt cheated spending that kind of money on something I could make at home, so I ended up getting the snapper and was happy with  it.

Anyway, wouldn't come here again but I enjoyed it nonetheless.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I think of Momo's as the ultimate 3 Martini Lunch --at least for this neighborhood.  The service is great, the food is great, and if you want to meet a girlfriend for giant salads and cocktails, Momo's is ideal.  

It's definitely not an every day sorta thing --it's for day's right after payday , when you don't have afternoon meetings, and it's OK to take 2 hours and come back with a little buzz.  As the quintessentially responsible employee, I want to make it clear that I would *NEVER* do that!  But if I did, Momo's would be high on the list.
author: Amy A.

description: I would venture to say that momo's has the best Cobb salad in town.  I go there for business lunches and I try and try other items on the menu but I can't get away from the Cobb.  Everything I have had has been excellent but if you are a salad fan, they are pretty dang good here.  My sister had the Chicken Pot Pie and I must say it was off the chain as well.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Don't get me started on this place. I'm not hatin (a little bit) but I've eaten in, picked up food, and sat at the bar in this place and the service always leaves me with a bad taste in my mouth. Every time I eat there I say to myself, "why was I so l lazy, I should have cooked". 

It is what it is....a place to get knackered after a ballgame. I live down here and during baseball season, it's a sea of orange and black retardedness. If your single and want to hook up with some cougar or sloppy bridge and tunnel action...go.

They seem to have drama over there too. One of my clients used to work for them too and they screwed her on serious overtime....bad ju-ju!! You must ensure that service providers get treated right. Serving food is not easy.
author: Bill M.

description:
I went here last night before the Giants game and found beers to be $7 for a little plastic cup.  I should've just bought a beer at the ballpark!  The bartender couldn't even pour it right either....  

On to the food...

I ordered a $32 new york steak cooked medium rare and it came out WELL DONE!  Well maybe it was medium well but man....  How can you justify charging $32 for a new york strip that isn't even grilled properly.  We needed to get to the game so I didn't send it back.  The green beans that came with the steak were even worse.

So basically, I am never going back there....  Better to go to Acme Chophouse for a steak.  At least it's cooked properly!
author: Derrick V.

description:
The owner Pete is sooo nice; he came over and introduced himself. 

I went to Momo's one day for lunch. I ordered a Roasted Chicken Breast & Pear Salad with Candied Walnuts and Dried Cranberries with Whole Grain Mustard Vinaigrette. This was a tasty salad that didn't leave me hungry after lunch! 

The servers were very attentive to my needs and polite. 

I want to go back and try something different!
author: J-nine I.

description:
We went here for a group lunch today, and it wasn't  too bad.  I have only ever seen this place (across the street from San Francisco's world-famous Phone Company Park) before and after Giants games...thought it was a sports bar, but they surprised me by being a real restaurant.  

The service wasn't awesome, but it was definitely passable.  The food wasn't awesome either, considering the price, but was satisfying enough.  I am starting to get a touch of heartburn now though (I had the French Onion soup) which is never a good thing.  I don't know if I will ever eat here again, not that it was bad...just wasn't GREAT!  If you want to come here, I suggest going at lunch - you would avoid the baseball crowds and drunkies that a lot of other peeps mention in their reviews...
author: Jessica B.

description: Three stars for the convenient location to grab a drink before going to a game, but nothing else seemed exciting about the place.
author: Job E.

description:
Just a little shoutout to Desiree, the super awesome server last Saturday at Emily's bridal shower luncheon.

We had the back dining room, and Em's aunt decorated to the max. 

Desiree was super friendly, helpful, and efficient. She kept the appletinis and mojitos coming. Nice job.

The food was good too.
author: Misha F.

description: My first time to visit Momo's today before opera at the ballpark. Excellent service! Great atmosphere. Pulled pork sliders and steak skewers were perfect for quick bite before heading across the street.
author: CS W.

description:
The food and service were surprisingly good.  The ambiance presented as a touristy, generic place.  However, the food was delicious.  Loved the wedge salad.  Fair pricing.  Lovely waiter.

Problem:  We dined early and had to endure the sounds of an old-school, punitive-rather-than-inspiring line-up in the next room.  Ridiculous.  The MOD was breathing down necks.  Our waiter was smart and skilled.  The bussers were excellent.  They didn't need the manager hissing "who has table _#_?__" the minute we placed the credit card into the book.  The credit card had only been down 5 seconds.  We would have rather waited the full one minute for the waiter than to have had to imagine what it is like to work for this guy!  Hopefully I've jumped to wrong conclusions and everyone has a blast working at MoMo's.  They do a good job.
author: Gen d.

description:
YAWN!

Didn't want to give this place a two but I have experienced better and that's what 2 stands for on yelp so a 2 it is ...

I have season tickets to the Giants games and have only been inside Momo's once. Never again. It was like I was back in college with everyone trying to look happy as they ordered $7.00 lemonjellos on a credit card tab (Ok now, painful later). Very preppy as you approach the barstools with eager bartenders looking for big tips from smiling, dizzy drunks arguing over who is going to win, who sucks, who hates Barry, or whatever complete strangers can argue about. And the wait for a drink (coke for me) is ice age long unless you have been feeding the servers dollars to get them to rush back to you in the heartcrushing, sweaty crowd of people, mostly men. Too bad but I hardly ever see many girls inside Momo's, they tend to bunch outside in the breeze. Smart thinking, I think.

Man, the money this place pulls in during Giant season, it must be in the atmosphere because it is always out the door, down the street crowded before the games. Personally, I try to always get my car valet parked here (it used to be 15.00, then 20.00, the 25.00) but if they go up any more I am going to park by the Flower Mart and walk in. Good stretch of the legs but I always feel better too.

Anyway, I have never eaten anything here other than the fries which were way overpriced and bland so if that is any indication, it doesn't seem like the food is a focus of their attention.

Offseason, I can't imagine this place being busy. Who is around here to keep the doors open with all of the better restaurants around along wth the new Safeway down the street. Normal people would never put up with the prices this establishment charges if they didn't have to.

And what's with all the T-shirt sellers out the door, down the steps now? Could you make it any more crowded than it already is?

Momo's is good for bringing out-of-towners for a visit but for "locals", it's kind of passe.
author: Terry H.

description: You are going to a Giants game and after taking BART and the MUNI train over you get a bit thirsty, so naturally you hit up MoMo's for a beer or two or three regardless if its a day or night game.  They are slow as the Mississippi mud at the bar for service but they are on average at least $2 cheaper than the beer inside the park.  The location alone and the prices makes it the spot before and after the game.
author: Tom Y.

description:
meh.

I'd like to say I'd give a place with 200+ reviews and 3 stars the benefit of the doubt, but I usually don't have high expectations and this time, rightfully so.

To sum up what so many yelpers have already said:

1. This place is packed to the brim before a Giants game. Good luck finding parking.
2. If you look 16, they'll card you at the front steps before the door. (P.S. I look 16, it's ok, I accept it)
3. Food is standard, somewhat forgettable; not good, not bad, not great.
4. The crispy ricotta and spinach gnocchi that comes with the braised short ribs are not gnocci at all. In fact, there isn't even any potato in it. It's just fried ricotta mixed with spinach in a round-ish shape that somewhat resembles gnocci. They tricked me!
5. Why are all the servers and bus-ers male?
6. Service is S L O W. Even when the place cleared out and ppl left to go to the game, it didn't get any better. We were there for 3+ hours. Let me say that again, we were there for OVER THREE HOURS. Not by choice, but because that's how long it took to get our drinks, to get our food, to get our dessert, to get our check. And I practically had to dance on the table to ever get our waiter's attention.

Alright, so that may have been a not so standard list of things about Momo's, but there you have it. Standard food, higher than standard prices, lower than standard service. I would've given it three stars, but the description for two stars is "Meh. I've experienced better." That seems to fit, so two stars it is.
author: Christine L.

description:
I have really great memories at MoMo's....  where do I begin?  Partying here before the World Series game in 2002, meeting up with pals before hitting a Giants game, drinks after work when I worked around the corner, brunch on numerous Giants' opening days....  and on and on.

I just can't believe I have not reviewed this restaurant until now.  I have been here so many times and the majority of those times have been excellent experiences.  

I am not a fan of getting cocktails in a plastic cup, but I do understand that they need to be careful on the patio when loads of drunk Giants fans are frolicking.

Unfortunately, I haven't been here in a while... I found Acme to be an easier choice as far as making reservations and the crowd factor recently.  But I have always liked their menu.  I have been to MoMo's for brunch, lunch & dinner and the food quality has always been pretty good with lots of variety.  Standouts for me are the caesar salad, fried calamari and ahi tuna sandwich.
author: Sheila D.

description:
I like mash potatoes after a baseball game. :]
I like their burgers, Idunno, I feel retarded.
I know people that work there. ^__^V 
But that's not why I give them 5 stars, it's because I'm just in love with their flaky mash potatoes. :]
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
The only reason I come here... pre-game beers.

There are about 50 cents cheaper than at the ballpark.

Really, that's it... it's like pre-partying at a friends before you go bar hoppin... you gotta go somewhere after your drunken train ride up to PacBell, eh... At&t park... whatever.
author: Kris I.

description:
My friends and I waited forever for our food to arrive.
You'd think a fancy restaurant like MoMo's would have better service. 

Their gumbo was good but it was overpriced! 
There was hair in my friend's food. He got another entree on the house and us girls got free desserts because of the mishap. 

Ehh, I won't be coming back. 

The End.
author: Bianca B.

description:
Who said you can't turn down a free meal?  I've been here a few times, all free, courtesy of open table

Nothing really good here.  I had the Crab salad and it was like, "huh, this would cost $19?"  You know that special sauce in your big mac? It's the same sauce, altered thousand island, calling it their special dressing.  I had the ribs a few times, but I think they had to fry it on one of the occasions because of the time factor.  The pot roast?  You can probably get something better at a diner.  The Fish was good tho.  I no longer eat there even when it's free.

This place is pretty pricey.  It must be the location, because they sure didn't spend it on the food.

**Ladies; If you chose this restaurant and you are thinking of putting out because this is like your 5th date, It AIN"T WORTH it!  Find somewhere else to go.

**Guys: If you thinking of getting some, taking a girl to this place, you are soooooo wrong.  Take her to a better place, you will probably even save some money.  My friend got some love on a first date with some Mc Nuggets and you can too!

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
Availability for reservations was good.

Parking took like FOREVER because the Kaboom festival was going on (almost near the end), which my friends and I were unaware of. Other than that, I'm pretty sure on a normal night wouldn't be so bad.

Our waiter seemed pretty moody. He was nice in the beginning, then he turned into a little bee-otch and then back to somewhat nice. Maybe he was having a rough night? I don't know. 

Moving along to food....

For appetizers we had crispy calamari, hummus and pita bread, and pancetta wrapped prawns. All three were pretty delicious... unfortunately they were only short lived. 

The $29 "juiciest" steak comes with 2 sides and dessert: good deal, but not so juicy. It comes with horseradish mashed potatoes (I just don't happen to be a fan of horseradish, but if you like, then you may like this). A side of mooshrums come along side and those are pretty delish as well. As for dessert, you have your choice of chocolate volcano cake or an ice cream sundae. Half of us got one and the other half the other. Turns out, the volcano cake only tastes good a la mode... so you NEED both in order to enjoy the dessert.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Across from AT & T Park this place is decent from my experience here.

Decent menu for brunch,lunch or dinner.

It can get crowded here regardless if it is before or after a game.Lunch here during the week can be a little busy,but the people who work here are quick to make the customer's happy.


What I like: Nice selection of white/red wines.I really go for the white.The red has "watch-out" for that girl written all over it.I like red,but I don't desire much of it.

Just to name a few things here:

Appetizers: 

Fried Onion Rings were tasty,yes they were.
Bruschetta with Olive Bread, Prosicutto and Grilled Veggies,very good.

Salads:

A good selection and very tasty.


Entrees:

Gumbo with Andouille Sausage,Chicken and Gulf Shrimp is tasty also.

Macaroni and Cheese and many more. I was happy overall with each meal here.


Dessert: My choice sorbet (yummy)

I have told other people who are in this area to drop by here.

Decent food.

I don't want to go on and on,but it is worth trying out.
author: Dani D.

description:
The bearded waiter,
stares down the top of her dress,
expensive, bad food.
author: Mason G.

description:
This place is all fancy schmancy and stuff. I liked it! 

Holly and I got waaaaaaaay too much food because we just so happened to be hooked up with a $150 gift card from some lawyer that worked in her space that is currently working in France. Lucky us! 

So we got the artichoke AND the bruschetta for our appetizers. Very good. Got a nice glass of Malbec. Very good. Main course for me was the mahi mahi and she got the shirt steak (very good - but didn't finish all of it because we wanted to save room for.... drumroll ... dessert!) Dessert was by far the best part of the meal. Banana bread pudding w/ chocolate caramel drizzle AND the creme brulee. I couldn't crack the creme brulee as much as I'd like ;) but it was absolutely decadent. 

Service was great... very attentive. I spilled my wine on the white tablecloth just to bring some class... That was embarrassing but they took it pretty well. :) After the meal I felt like I was going to vomit or die ... one or the other but not both. It put me into a food-induced coma and I passed out at 7pm. 

Please. I probably won't go again just because it's so expensive but it was pretty nice. If you have something to celebrate ... and I mean as in... you won the lottery - go ahead! It's like one of those places your rich grandparents take you to when you're a little kid and you don't appreciate it half as much as you should.
author: Ash G.

description:
THERE WAS A FLY IN MY SOUP.  It didn't just land there, it was marinated in there. You'll be happy to know I hadn't taken a bite yet...BUT WHAT IF I HAD??!! I probably would have reenacted the scene from Ace Ventura where he burns his clothes and plunges his face with the toilet plunger.

The other food is good, but hellsa expensive for what it is. Go to Pete's. It's owned by the same people, but cheaper.
author: Eli B.

description:
My boyfriend found a hair in our onion strings we ordered.  We tell the bartender, but instead of replacing our dish he questions if it was our hair instead.  Then he says, Well... what do you want me to do about it? 

Don't even waste your time there.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Pazzzzzzzzz.

Please, whatever you do, skip this place. 

I went for lunch, it was raining, there was gumbo on the menu. . .hard to screw up? Apparently not.  The gumbo was $24, though I was assured by the waiter that it was "packed full of shrimp and chicken". Not $24 worth.

The wine had been open for a few days prior to serving it.  I don't usually order BTG, but I was alone, go figure.  The waiter offered to replace it the next time that I saw him, which happened to be right nbefore he handed me the check. . . he was pretty my absent the entire time.

Crappy wine list, average food quality and crappier service. Ughh.
author: Dash H.

description:
so sad! no more ladies happy hour on thursday nights. :( and they raised their martini happy hour prices to $5. oh well... all good things must come to an end.

great location across the best baseball park in the world. conveniently right off muni. martini's are yummy.
author: Kathleen J.

description: We used to go here before Giants games until some better places around the neighborhood opened up. It really seemed totally pointless to be paying practically the same price for a beer at Momos as you would inside the ballpark. For whatever reason, they always have the heatlamps on, even when it is packed, on like a 60' day. No thanks.
author: Jim B.

description: I approve of this establishment as it's close to sports and serves alcohol.
author: John S.

description:
I've eaten at Momo's several times for brunch and without fail they deliver a simple, tasty and well-priced meal.  

- Eggs benedict with potatoes which were perfectly cooked, crispy on the outside, and tender on the inside just the way I like them.

- Spacious seating at the bar area at 1 PM to watch football on 5 different flat screen TVs.  

- No long line, obnoxious waiters, or tourists invading this part of my 'hood.  

- No hassle parking, plenty of spaces on the street.

- A simple and easy to read menu with enough choices from traditional french toast to eggs, something for everyone if you're craving brunch.
author: Dennis M.

description:
You know, there's something about the atmosphere, the friendly staff that makes me want to love this place but no.
The food is ok, nothing memorable which means I can't remember what I ate here but I can still tell you about the tasty muffins and bread at Town's End around the corner.
So if you're in the neighborhood, you could do worse but...
author: Sean S.

description:
It was okay..service took like FOREVER! I sat...and sat...thought I was going to DIE of starvation...just when I was about to say "bye!" my food came. Its was okay. Then getting the check...ANOTHER STORY!
Now I just go there before my boys play ball! Good place to get drunk and then harrass the opposing team who show up at the ballpark lookin like CLOWNS!
author: Joanna H.

description: Non game day.  The service seriously sucked.  Even though our condo is across the street, we won't be back.
author: Brigid M.

description:
I'd have to say that they pick a beautiful spot for the restaurant. The food was OK. I wouldn't say it was all that great. The atmosphere was cool though!

This restaurant is right across the street from Pac-Bell park for all you SF Giants fans out there!

Go Giants!!
author: Wilson L.

description:
I thought this place was a great time. Of course it wasn't anywhere near a Giant's game so that may have helped. I went for a late lunch the first day I was in San Francisco and the place was pretty open. The atmosphere is fancy but still welcoming and comfortable. 

The food was all fantastic, but the prices were a little wild.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I see the so-so reviews and I'm guessing they are mainly from people going when it's way too crowded, like after a ballgame perhaps.  
We went at normal dinner time after Cirque du Soleil Kooza show, and grabbed a drink at the bar since we got there a little early for our reservation.  Food was awesome... I had the Herb Roasted Half Chicken with Spaghetti Squash and Sauted Mushrooms (all capitalized perfectly b/c I cut and pasted from their website), and my husband had the Grilled Ahi Tuna over Wasabi Mashed Potatoes with Mango Salsa.  It was nice!
author: Pancake ..

description: I was finally able to come here for the first time after hearing lots about it. My group of friends and I hung out at the bar/patio area on the 4th during the game, and we had a total blast. Such an awesome location being literally across the street from AT&T, and also within walking distance of many other restaurants/bars, BART, and Muni. The vibe was very loud with lots of yelling, which was definitely acceptable since it was during a game on July 4th. The beers were 6 bucks each, for any kind of beer; so obviously I was going for the Anchor Steams and Stellas rather than a Bud Light. We didn't get a chance to try the food but judging from the pictures I'm sure it is good. I highly recommend MoMo's if you're not going to the game, but still want that exciting, intense experience of being at one.
author: Anthony L.

description: Clearly avoid this place on Giants game days... duh. Way too crowded with drunk frat-boy types and those who slobber on them. But I went for the first time on a Sunday non-game day for an early dinner, and was surprised at how good the food and service was. The atmosphere is almost, dare I say, elegant. Great vintage SF photography. With all the giant screen tv's, this is an ideal place for watching other sports events. The drinks are pricey but food was fairly reasonably priced, generous portions and everything really delicious.
author: Philip M.

description: For some reason every time that I've dined here it feels like this restaurant just exudes an overly pretentious vibe for no good reason at all.  The food is expensive but only average, the service isn't that great even when it's not packed, and the patrons are generally ballpark goers with many representin' and wearing their Giants jerseys.  I just don't get what's up with this place, I always feel like I'm being snubbed by every employee, especially the managers or whoever the guys they have running around in suits are.  It's sad because this restaurant is in a great location for ballpark goers.  Too bad it wasn't a bar and grill.  To me, this restaurant is a little disappointing so I try to avoid it if I can.
author: Erich D.

description:
Dined about town here.  We hung out at the bar waiting for an increasing number of people to join us.  Our reservations originally for 4 grew to 7 then fell to 6.  Our server was pretty accommodating nonetheless.  Can I just say 6 dollars for an Amstel light... I know it's an import but shit I'm not at a club or anything... that's ridiculous.

The DAT menu looked real good, and I went with the Basil and Provolone Stuffed Chicken Breast Wrapped in Prosciutto and Served with Mashed Potatoes and Brussel Sprouts... for the main course yumm. Green salad and coffee ice cream for the 1st & 3rd.  Great service and kindly waitress.  I don't get the terrible ratings, maybe we were lucky.  I had a good time.  Minus the 6 dollar beer.  Boo that.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
Are you people crazy?  $$?  This is definitely spendy.  Dinner entrees generally range from $20 to $35 each.  I came here with my boyfriend and split a salad and an entree, and the bill came to nearly $40 before tax and tip.

Service was good, although we took off without dessert to avoid missing the Caltrain.  They probably could have accommodated us if we had remembered to mention that.
author: Sharon W.

description:
I wanted to write this review after Dine About Town 2008 but never got a chance to, so here I am now, a year later, giving it a higher rating than I would have initially. 

Their set menu from Dine About Town was forgettable. Why? Because i don't remember what i had. Even when I have the menus pulled up on my browser, I still can't remember what I had that day. The only thing I remember having is the Bittersweet Chocolate Volcano Cake with Fresh Berries and Whipped Cream. *drools. It was THE BEST!!! Gooey warm chocolate gushing out from the center of the warm chocolate outer layer with fresh raspberries and blueberries, YUMMY!

We sat outside on a beautiful sunny day before a Giants' night game and it was fun watching the Giants' fans walk by. 

The food:
- Half Dozen Oysters on the Half Shell: Delicious, minus the sand. Boo.
- Gumbo with Andouille Sausage, Chicken and Gulf Shrimp: The shrimp was cooked perfectly, the flavors were on point. Everything was just sooooo good.

This is a great place to go before, or after the game but the service is slow. We were ignored a good handful of times whenever we needed something. All the cocktails on the menu seemed yummy, so I will be coming back for some of those. So, minus one star.
author: Maggie H.

description:
Went here with my co-workers for dinner Thursday during the "Dine about Town" promotion. The waiter seemed offended when we asked for the Dine about Town menu. During our meal there was no re-filling of water/soda (w/o asking) nor a, "hows the food"? The waiter did stop by... but only to ask AGAIN what our dessert choices were.
I had the French Onion Soup, Basil and Provolone Stuffed Chicken Breast Wrapped in Prosciutto and Served with Mashed Potatoes and Brussel Sprouts, and the Ice Cream Sundae with Chocolate syrup. The food deserved 2.5 - 3 stars, nothing spectacular... The waiter we got that night brought down the whole experience.
author: Jeemster C.

description:
This place is awesome. It was my 1 year anniversary with my boyfriend and we went there after spending the day in the city. Our waitress was wonderful, spent time talking to us and got to know us. She even ended up discounting our drinks because she liked us so much!

The food was great, maybe a little pricey but you are right across from the ball park what do you expect. We had crab cakes for an appetizer which was SO fabulous!!

Drinks were strong and flowed continuously. We had dessert and even that was killer. I would totally recommend this place to anyone wanting a casual or even classy evening.
author: Colleen M.

description:
We have our company's team lunch here every Tuesday, and they're always so nice to us.

I'm a loser for always getting the same thing...perhaps next week I'll try something different?!

Great place to eat. Staff here is uber friendly and nice, and the foods delicious. A tad pricey, but still a great place to relax during the day with friends or co-workers, or enjoy a drink after work. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
This place is ... ok
Not spectacular but Ok.

I went for the dine about town special but decided to order off the regular menu.  I had a mimosa as it was supposed to be Brunch, the Caesar Salad and the Tombo Tuna Sandwich.  

The Mimosa was itty bitty for $9.00 - so overpriced for the size.

The Caesar Salad had too much dressing and some of it was pretty limp.  I am not sure if overly dressed salad becomes limp or if restaurants do this to hide the fact that the lettuce is not as fresh as it should be, but I've found this combination usually goes together.

The Tombo Tuna Sandwich was delicious however, I might even say delightful and made the mimosa and the Caesar Salad bearable.  It was an unusual combination that worked very well and the Tuna was not a Tuna Salad, but an actual piece of seared tuna.

The service was OK.  Friendly but a little sparse and the bill was not calculated properly.  They ended up charging everyone for the per piece menu instead of charging the dine about town prices to those who chose that option.  They fixed it once we caught it.

I am glad I went on a day that was uncrowded.  I've seen this place utterly swamped on game days and I have to say as tasty as the tuna was I can't see it being worth the crowd when coupled with the rest.
author: E R.

description: We had a nice brunch at MoMo's. The bottomless mimosas and buffet was much appreciated. Our waitress was cool and the manager came by to see how we were doing, which I thought that was nice. I've worked in food service and I always appreciate it when the manager drops by. It shows me they care, which is a good sign.
author: Scott C.

description:
1) Loved the service.  Prompt.  Attentive. Helpful
2) Liked the food. Apps (Crispy calamari and pancetta/prawns) very good.  The calamari was crispy and the prawns were flavorful and moist.  Chicken pot pies was delish.  Veggies were crispt and fresh. (Who wants mushy veggies?)  Creme brulee was yummy.  Not into the apple tart my dining companions had. Meh! Cooked apples. Yuk.
author: Mark C.

description:
I've only been to MoMo's after I couldn't find a scalped ticket/got kicked out of SBC for not being sober.  As I stumbled across the street in despair the din from MoMo's piqued my interest and I'm glad it did.  Not only was I surprised by the size and selection in the bar, I was surrounded by many fellow baseball fans, almost all supporting a rag-tag crew called the Giants.  Despite their despicable team, these fans welcomed me with open arms and we drank until baseball season was over (pretty impressive since I went there on opening day). 

Couldn't tell you much about the menu...
Couldn't tell you much about specials....
Couldn't even tell you where it is...

But god dammit I had a great time here and I guarantee you will too
author: Brian H.

description:
My friends and I ate here before the Giants game yesterday and had a great time. When we first walked in (we ate inside instead of the patio), I was a little worried because it looked so fancy. But there were actually a lot of affordable choices on the lunch menu. We got the turkey sandwich, the burger and the buffalo sandwich. The two sandwiches were both really, really good. My boyfriend said the burger was just okay. They cam with french fries which were crispy and delicious!

We would have been fine (our meals were all under $15), except my boyfriend was stupid enough to order shots at a place like this. He got us two rounds of Patron that ended up being $96. Stupid, stupid, stupid!!

So I would recommend this place for lunch before a game, just don't order liquor. Otherwise, you'll get better food and beer that's actually cheaper than if you ordered food inside the ballpark.
author: Caroline S.

description:
No funny review for this place this time.  But thats not necessarily a bad thing.  Went here for lunch on Sunday with the family.  The food was excellent, my Eggs Bennidict were perfect and everyone else thoroughly enjoyed their food.  The service was fantastic, our waiter was attentive but not annoyingly so.  As that crazy blond Goldylocks once put it, "It was juuussttt right."

Now for pregame drinks before a giants game, you can't get a better location than good old MoMo's.  Personally I love being able to throw down some good Scotch or a cocktail or ten before a game.  Heck if I am going to get nailed with expensive drinks that day I would rather be at MoMo's drinking the good shit than having to sell a kidney to pay for three drinks at the bar in the ball park.

This place is an institution, I hope it never goes away and the quality never drops (which I seriously can not forsee happening).

Definatly a place worth going, over and over and over again.
author: Carter H.

description:
If you are heading to AT&T park to check out the Giants whoop up on the hated Dodgers, then this is the place you must come before.

A great spot to mingle with fellow Giants fan and talk a little smack to Dodger (or any other team) fans.  The drinks are a bit pricey, but it's all worth it when you get a little buzz going and you go watch Tim Lincecum mow down batters like he's cutting his lawn on Sunday.

And after the game, it's the perfect palce to have that one drink that sends you over the edge, from just drunk to absolutely spinning.  A fine way to end the evening.
author: Lucas N.

description: We stopped in for a quick bite before going to see Cirque du Soleil Totem down the street.  The bartender was our waiter.  He made a great bloody maria (tequila), was friendly, informative and attentive.  We split a meal and he brought it out on two plates.  The salad was fresh greens with light dressing and the fries were light and crispy. They were awesome. I'm sure it's different before games, but we were able to eat at the bar and enjoy the games on the tv's.
author: Linda C.

description:
My brother in law through my sister a 30th surprise party here! Whatta great choice! We had a pre-fixed menu for our party of 60 or so. Before the surprise we had a cocktail hour and the service was excellent. The waiters were very helpful and prompt with drinks. 

After the surprise we were in a private dinig area. The food was DELICIOUS! The steak was perfect...like BUTTER. It may have been a bit rarer than most people like it but it was yummy! We got dessert on top of the birthday cake as well. Chocolate Lava cake was YUMMO! Again service during dinner was excellent. They didn't even kick us out when we were supposed to be done. I am definitely coming back here again.
author: Jazmine S.

description:
This place sucks, period.  It's a waste of a space - they have all the right ingredients for an awesome restaurant yet manage to screw up the one key piece that would make it legendary... the food!  

The location, ambiance, decor and *ahem price are up to par with San Francisco's finest but the food is garbage.

Do yourself a favor and avoid this place - unless you're popping in for a drink before a game!
author: Ricky S.

description:
Mediocre food for almost-ballpark prices. 

I paid $13 for a hamburger that was bland and underdone. Beers are really expensive as well. 

The fries, however, were amazing. Just get a plate of those and you'll be set. 

I'd find somewhere else to go to get your pre-game beering in.
author: Theo C.

description:
So I finally made it to this place after Friday's Giants v Dodgers game and was thoroughly disappointed. The line to get in looked long but we got in soon enough.

The place is packed and everyone is pushing their way to the bar. Margaritas are ok but for $8 they should be better; they use Montezuma Tequila. I guess as I get older I don't want to put up with this obnoxious crap.

We head to the patio and it too crowded. I ask a busboy/barkeep why the opposite patio, which is entirely empty, isnt opened. He doesnt have an answer for me.

After dropping about $200 amongst the group for drinks we get to Midnight when the bouncers decide to close the place down and don't give us a chance to finish, tells us to take them out on the street.

Nice job guys!
author: Chris J.

description: I went here before the Giants game and it was the perfect pre-game spot! It wasn't too crowded and we were able to get drinks immediately. Lots of other Giants fans to schmooze with, too! I've also heard the food is delicious so I will definitely be going back. Oh yeah, and Go Giants!!
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Yawn. This place is terribly overpriced (I paid $100 for two meals and a "cheap" bottle of wine) and the food is average. Momo's is located right across from the Giants stadium so the fact that prices are hiked up and the menu doesn't take risks is not surprising.

I've never been here at night; maybe it's better suited as a bar. Still, I'm not enthused enough about this place to find out.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Olive Garden-ish food with nice patio area on sunny days.  

Wine list isn't impressive, but very reasonably priced - they don't pad too much.

Cool name and great location.
author: Nana S.

description:
This restaurant is conveniently located across from PacBell Park. I came here specifically for the Dine About Down event. They had more than enough choices for a first timer. My friends and I were seated at a corner booth and the waiter promptly came to take our order. We placed our order and proceeded to the bar for drinks.

I had no idea what I wanted to order so I asked for the bartender's suggestion. I wanted a drink that's sweet and made with vodka. I had the raspberry cosmo, which was delicious because it was smooth. The bartender didn't skimp on the vodka - he kept pouring. The overall service at the bar was poor - it took forever for our drinks to be rung up. The bar wasn't busy that day and it would have been a quick transaction if he was sober. My friends ordered mojitos and he made it the lazy way (didn't crush the mint leaves).

By the time we get back to our table, the appetizers had already arrived. The waiter made a stink about ordering drinks through the bar and not through him. Not everybody wanted drinks and we wanted to keep the drinks separate. 

I ordered the following:

Appetizer - Steamed mussels with pancetta, olives and sweet vermouth
Entre - Grilled skirt steak with potato gratin, green beans, braised onions and Portobello mushrooms
Dessert - Chocolate brioche banana bread pudding

I got more mussels than expected (a plate of 10) and the sauce was tasty and great for dipping bread in. The entre was well proportioned: a pile of steak with a sprinkling of mushrooms on top, a stack of crunchy green beans, and a hefty potato cake. The steak was just perfect at medium and I enjoyed every bite. The potato cake was baked and contained a layer of heavy cream in the middle. It was too heavy for my taste but it was ok. The best part of the meal was dessert. The banana bread pudding drizzled in caramel sauce was light.
I had a chance to sample the duck confit and the volcano cake. The duck was tender and juicy (almost like chicken). The volcano cake was drenched in chocolate sauce and was very rich. 

Overall, the dining experience was fair. The lighting was dimmed to create a romantic atmosphere. The setting for dinner was nice - white table cloth and silverware. The service for dinner was quick. I would come back again for the food.
author: Candace F.

description:
Very greeeassy overpriced food. 
If you love eating bricks of butter then it's the spot for you.

They used to be better until they cut back on their portions and less attention to detail in taste and preperation. The scallop dish went from 6 pieces to 4 for a whopping $30-35! Yikes.

I can't figure out if it's suppose to be a place for elegant dinning or a normal over hyped restaurant.

Everything you can expect from and expensive over priced place.
author: Trevor L.

description:
Oh, we make the mistake about every six months or so.   "Why don't we see if MoMo's has gotten any better?"  Then we go, get ignored by the sloppy wait staff and suffer the crappy food.  

Last time the server refused to write the order down...yes my bride can order in a slightly high maintenance manner....yes its smart when taking her order to write it down...but hey, I married her right....anyway...

The guy refuses to write it down and of course f'd it up.  Ribs with Kraft BBQ sauce.  Lousy COLD beef barley soup...oops, forgot the shrimp.

We are amazed every time....great location....nice space...and the chef owner doesn't want to show up and get this place right.  I think that he is content to sell alot of beer during baseball season...then he takes six months off.  Too bad for South Beach...we'd love a great neighborhood spot to call home.
author: G-Rex R.

description: After being scammed out of a opening day ticket. I went here to drink and watch the game. It  was packed and I loved it! I saw a lot of people knew,so it was good time! I think I will come back for more day games.
author: Brian B.

description: Meatballs tasted like paper.  potatoes were very under cooked.
author: jonathan m.

description: The ho hum, uninspired dishes and poor service makes for yet another chapter in my "Squandered San Francisco business opportunities" book. I am not convinced that the revenue from the baseball season will carry this place much longer during the off season. Who actually dines here? The food is a two [stars] at best. It is a convenient place to have a beverage or two before the game, but Paragon is significantly better. It's location is its' only saving grace; perhaps that is all that is required to sustain this place, but not on my green backs.
author: Michael G.

description:
Went there for lunch on a non-Giants game day, so I'd consider this a pretty fair review.  Reason being that Momo's is across from the ballpark and most of the reviews are people whining about getting elbowed by a Dodgers fan, or because a waitress was "short" with them while trying to balance orders from a dozen drunken baseball fans.  To these people; Schwartzeneggar says: "Stop Whining!"

http://www.collegeslackers.com/soundboard/arnold_schwarzenegger

And back to the review:

For the price, the food was sub-par.  Nothing special here.

Our waitress was so pitiful that calling her a "rookie" would be letting her off easy.  We were trying to decide between buying a bottle, and just getting a few glasses, and after several back and forths where it was clear that she didn't really grasp the difference (we were thinking about price and volume), we just decided on two glasses each.  First, she thought we were ordering an extra empty glass, because that would clearly make sense (WTF?).  Then, she tried to bring the second glasses out while we were about HALFWAY through our first glasses, assuming she would just plop them down on the table.  Perhaps I shouldn't be so harsh; I'd assume it was her first day on the job, but please, MoMo's: either train your staff, or just hire some common sense.  Customers are clients, not cattle.

At this point, I wasn't sure if she was going to bring our check, or strap an oat-bag over my head like I was Seabiscuit after a race.
author: Nate H.

description: Where do I begin. We just walked out of momo's without a drink or food! We're now at Pete's Tavern happy as a clam. I arrived at Momo's with my kids and husband. We walked to the bar and found an open table. We sat and sat and sat... I didn't realize you had to order at the bar until I felt completely ignored and thought to myself maybe we order at the bar. I'm fine with that - no big deal. Well then I stood at the bar for several minutes then walked back to my table and tried again to order at the bar, this time both kids hanging on the table top waiting to order. There were several patrons, not busy at all. After 5 minutes standing there the bartender ignored me and the kids and helped 2 people that just arrived and sat down. I was disappointed and kinda pissed. So, note to the bartender lady, quit if your not happy, smile a little more and take a breath. Life could be worse. We heard great things of Momo's. Unfortunately we will not be returning and as a business owner feel that customer service drives business and repeat customers.
author: Brian O.

description: We went here to get dinner but got there early so we still had the brunch menu at 4pm. It was a great dining experience; the hostess was very kind and took our jackets. My meal of french dip roll was excellent, and I heard similar reviews from the rest of my family members. Overall, it was a great dinner and I would return!
author: Olivia s.

description: Back when I worked at 3rd and Townsend, I'd come here for the Chinese Chicken Salad and a side of mashed potatoes at lunch. Haven't been here in years, though.
author: Miriam W.

description: I have had lunch here a few times and the food was always really tasty.  They have good salad, sandwiches and some other more expensive entrees I haven't tried.  The patio is great for pre-Giants games, since the beer is about half the price of whats inside the ballpark.  Good crowd also.  Probably wouldn't go here unless going for a game though.
author: James H.

description: Great burgers and even better drinks!  This place screams Martini to me and I listen!
author: Eileen L.

description:
Wandered here looking for lunch, and found overpriced, uninspired American food in large portions, in a bland-yet-stuffy generic dining room full of white guys in khakis.

So, all those mediocre reviews about eating here before games?  They apply other times as well.
author: Hans G.

description:
2-stars for the overpriced wannabe glam food
3-stars for the fun level before and after Giants games.

This review must be split into two: one for food, one for game days.
1. Food - we came here as a last resort because Paragon ended being closed on Sundays. We just wanted a good burger and some artery hardening fried foods at a decent bar food price so we figured Momo's would offer this - not so much. The restaurant and the bar share the same expensive menu - the $16 basket of calamari (granted they give you a lot, but because there's so much, there's no way 2 people can share 2 apps and still make it to an entree), $24 bbq platter with 2 links, 3 ribs, 2 lil chicken pieces, beans, and coleslaw. That's what my friend and I shared. And those were basically the cheapest items on the menu. 

This place is a lil overpriced and the bartender couldn't even tell us what was good on the menu! We asked him what foods Momo's was known for and he hesitated and then said, "We're known for being across from the ballpark!" 

2. Drink Scene on Game Days - great place to go for drinks before and after the game. If clausterphobia is your thing, this won't be your place because it gets crowded. They even have a boombox outside providing the "music". Don't look to meet the man/woman of your dreams here, just come for a good time and meaningless yet fun conversations with strangers and $6 beers.
author: Jessica C.

description:
not really impressed with food.
Quite expensive but good volume of food. 

I don't come here at least someone takes me there with their treat
author: Cindy N.

description:
I've only been here a handful of times. Once for brunch (meh). Other times for pre and post game festivities.

It doesn't do anything for me, but wow, lucky Momo's...talk about placement! Good call there. Don't go for the food. It's not all that, but definitely hit it up for the pre-and post-game stuff, but just so you know, it's crowded, it's like the marina vacated and showed up here, and you'll probably wind up wearing half your drink because it's packed like that. Or maybe because I'm five feet tall and people just don't see me. Life sucks for shorties.
author: Charlene L.

description:
It's definitely a bunch of blue shirts back slapping and ass grabbing.  But sometimes you just need a little of that, you know??

It's crowded and loud, obnoxious and ultimately, can be really fun if you're in the mood.

Stay outside, the food is just so-so.
author: Alison R.

description:
Meh. Middle of the road, so no more than three stars. Nothing specifically pissed me off, so no less than three either.

I went here for lunch on my first day of work in San Francisco. The menu is rather uninspired Americana. The atmosphere is pleasant but, again, uninspired.

I arrived around noon and was in a sea of middle-aged men in suits. By the end of our two-hour lunch, though, the crowd had transitioned to 30-something men in $200 jeans.

I ordered a salad, which was fine but nothing you can't get anywhere else, and the crab cakes. The crab cakes themselves had good amounts of crab meat, but they were deep-fried, which isn't nearly as good as pan-fried in my book. Also, they were served on a bed of corn, which was weird, and just drizzled with the sauce. I would have been much happier with a little extra to dip my crab into. 

For dessert, I got some chocolate caramel something-or-another off of the almost-funny-it-is-so-standard dessert menu (sorbet? check! chocolate lava cake? check! carrot cake? check! fried banana thing? check! tiramisu? check!) It tasted pretty good and wasn't overwhelmingly huge. 

So um, yeah....
author: Lauren H.

description:
I have to say, MoMo's is tied for first with Pete's Tavern for the #1 Pregame for Giants games. I miss it in the off-season so much that sometimes I drive by and reflect on all of the good times i've had there. I can't wait until the Emerald Bowl when SC colors flood the bar.

See you soon MoMo's...it's been too long.
author: Anna F.

description:
Mixed bag.  The baseball crowd is a lot rowdier and rambunctious than the non-b&t peeps.  I could care less.  Its a nice place if you have good seating.  
I agree with most that the food is pricey.
Again, my experience w/servers has been both good and bad.  
We did have a problem with them once even when we had reservations.
author: Frank A.

description:
fellow giants fans, this is our place! 

this place is amazing and a fun place to be if you don't have tickets to the game and even if you do, come here before or after the game!!!

they have delicious salmon, appetizers and drinks!! 

the staff is great and the owner is awesome.. He owns a few places in SF.. 

MOMO'S is delicious!! you must go!! very fun!! :) 

that's where I will be the days that the giants are playing the rangers in texas in the world series, the days the giants are in SF, well MOMO'S I will see you for some drinks to celebrate after the game! ;)
author: rachel g.

description:
This place is ok.

I have gone there for lunch during the week and usually you see alot of people on lunch breaks hanging out enjoying their meal. Nice atmosphere during the work week. However,I can't imagine going before or after a game.

I hate to have to go back to work after a good meal. Why not go straight to "HAPPY HOUR"...


Funk da work stuff.(yes,I spelled it that way).
author: Mattee M.

description:
We had dinner here before going over to see Cirque du Soleil.  I'd only recommend 2 things - the drinks (which I didn't try) and appetitzers.  
Our group enjoyed their fried calamari ($15 large order) which came with ketchup and tartar sauce, wedges of lemon.  The shoestring onion rings which Yelpers recommended, was OK.  A bit too oily.  I wouldn't order again. Their thin crust Margarite pizzas ($14) were good, but small portions.  
I steered away from the $29 prix fixe 3 course dinner of NY steak.  Hubby tried it & said the beef was tough, "been dead a long time".  The fries which came with it looked like the perfectly formed frozen kind. He liked his dessert, a pineapple sorbet.  I tried the chicken/sausage gumbo.  It was spicy and extremely thick with a tablespoonful of long grain white rice on the bottom.  It was good but I prefer my gumbos with a little more liquid in it.  My Caesar salad was disappointing.   Pieces of romaine lettuce, dressing and ample cheese.  No anchovy!

Our waitress was very nice, but the bus boy was another matter.  We couldn't finish our meal and asked to pack it.  He gave this look of disagreement (hubby only ate 1/2 his steak).  Made you feel as if you were bothering him with extra work.  I'm not sure I'd recommend the place for food other than appetizers.  My friends did enjoy their cocktails 'tho.  The restaurant atmosphere is very nice for dining and they have lots of old SF photos on the wall, including ones where the GG Bridge was being built.
author: Ry T.

description:
i went with 6 friends on a Thursday night and the waiter didn't really seem to care from the start. we asked for the dine about town menu after we looked over the regular menu and he looked pissed. when i asked if there  were anchovies in the Caesar salad, he said, "there's some in the dressing, but you can't taste it." when i told him i asked because i was allergic to fish, he didn't seem to care or believe me. three of us ordered the skirt steak and he didn't even ask how we want the beef cooked.

one of my friends had an amex gift card she got and it was still in its packaging saying "$25," and when the waiter came back, he said it got denied. she told him it was new and asked if he could try it again. he came back and said there's only $20 on it and that she could cover the rest on another card or by cash. she told him it was okay because "we already gave too much tip."

the only good service from this place was from the friendly hostess who took us to our table and got our coats from coat-check and the two Asian  gentlemen who refilled out glasses of water right away when we asked and when we wanted to take our leftovers to go.

the food was okay, its in a great location, but i wouldn't go back. not even for a beer after the game. the waiter totally killed what could have been an okay experience.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I ate here with a big group of co-workers (thankfully the company paid). My eggplant parmesan was good, but not amazing (GBNA). The pulled pork sandwich platter with fries was the way to go to get a lot of bang for your buck. That sucker was huge, but sadly I didn't get to try it. Basically the food was fine, but no raves were heard.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
This place is always a hit or miss.  I've been here for many a going away parties and I've enjoyed from the good drinks to the good food.  Then again they have a lot of pre game parties here since its just across the street from SBC.  During those pre game parties it just way over crowded and the drinks are weak!

I say stay away from that part of town unless you're going to watch the game!
author: Harry H.

description:
Who cares if its crowded, overpriced ? Well its MoMo's- its been a haven for those who didnt get their tickets in time, got rounds of shots (alright it helps being pretty or decked out in your juicy couture outfit) and yes gives you a vantage point to look out into the entrances (to watch the lines thin out)... and well if you just want to meet locals who'll give you their reasons why the Giants are going to win the game- be very verrrrry happy !  Enjoy the patio on those sunny day games- when you're playing hookie with the rest of the 9 to 5vers ;-)

UPDATE: Fleet Week '07

So I finally ate here for brunch- the review is to cover the Eggs Benedict List! Although the service was prompt and attentive- the Eggs Benedict lacked the punch I was looking for.  Poached eggs yolks did not melt to cover the biscuit and hollandaise lacked flavor.  
This brunch plate is about a 2 stars :-(  So I demoted from my original review of 5 stars (bar atmosphere and location) to 4 stars- minus the one star for poor rendition of this breakfast gem!
author: Arissa C.

description:
I can't say enough nice things about the people at MoMo's. We went there for lunch to celebrate my grandmother's 90th birthday, and from the moment we arrived until we left, the staff bent over backwards to make our experience special. 

We brought our own cake and the pastry chef made it look great and brought out fresh whipped cream, and our server was great, always checking in with us making sure things were ok. 

The food was delicious too - especially the tuna tartare.
author: Nicki H.

description:
Heard much about this place from various people - but experience did not live up to the hype. 

Greatest attribute is location near baseball park, and near Muni and Caltrain lines. Enviroment inside is nice, and will satisfy business and casual clientale. Also, seems like happy hours are fun. 

Downside is that the food is not great - especially considering that for the hefty prices (think $25 entrees), the dishes should satisfy beyond regular diner fare. Sure, there is fancy food plated with style - but WOW, it was not. Definitely possible to use the $$ budget around the Embacadero and downtown and eat much better!
author: MandS R.

description:
Huge party spot for Ballpark fans and urban cougar fans. 

I've gone here several times for a solo supper at the bar. The food is ok. The beer selection is great. I prefer the service in the bar rather than in the restaurant even thought the bar is almost always noisy.  I had a couple of bad experiences with the service in the restaurant. Won't bother with that again.
author: Sirima S.

description:
Had lunch here with my daughter. I had a grilled Tuna sandwich and she had the chicken pot pie. My sandwich was okay, but she really didn't like the pot pie. She only managed to eat a few bites.

I had been here before and was equally unimpressed. For what it's worth the service was good and they do have a killer onion string appetizer.
author: Wayne P.

description: I love this restaurant.  Great decor.  Service is generally good.  The food is decent and reasonable priced.  I've been to this restaurant dozens of times -- I've had brunches, lunches and dinners here.   I think they make the best Salmon in town.  I love the name MoMos!  I walk by this place numerous times when the Giants are in town -- always packed; a very good sign.  If you want to avoid the crowd, go there when the Giants are not playing at home.
author: Peace L.

description:
Is it me or is everything on the menu salty?
Probably to cover up the crappy ingredients or cooking they do here.

The food is average, if it were reasonably priced.  $14 mac and cheese with ham, $8 drinks, and $9 french onion soup which sucked.  C'mon, this is a tourist trap.  Go up the street to Paragon or 21st Amendment, its well worth the walk.

BTW, whats up with the hotties on the pics here?  I didn't see them, but if I do, I'll give this place 2 stars.
author: J S.

description:
I've heard plenty of things about this place, and decided to finally try it out during the MLB All-Star game festivities, of all days. The place was packed, but of course it was the All-Star Game. Walking past this restaurant during regular Giants games, it seems to be a little less packed, but still crowded for a typical restaurant.

After going inside, I was surprised at the ambiance of the place. I thought it would be some kind of sports bar theme, but it was nicer than what I expected. 

The good was also good. I had the NY strip steak, and it was prepared just as I ordered. The price might have been a little too high for steak since the filet mignon was only $1 less than the strip steak. The bread served alongside the food was crunchy as hell, but I guess that's how they cook it. The dessert was also good (typical creme brulee).
author: Chris F.

description:
This place has the IDEAL locale...directly across the street from the ballpark, on the CORNER no less, with a fairly large patio.  And of course, with the weather being nice, the masses were out and about Friday night after work!  Thank god we got a table.  That's where the goodness ends.

They had ONE freaking server for the ENTIRE patio on a FRIDAY evening on a WARM day!  WTF!  Who's running this joint?  It was about an hour before we even got a menu.  And if I weren't already drunk off a crapload of Stellas and Patron shots, I would've been more pissed.  And $12 for Patron?  It's not like you're some upscale lounge or anything!

Still, I'll say that the blond, female bartender there was the SHIZZNET and was really cool.  Even on a stifling day, in her lame abusive uniform of button up shirt and tie, sweating her ass off, she was still awesome.  Thanks.
author: Susan L.

description: This is for desserts only.  Good brioche bread pudding and chocolate lava cake.  Seems like a good place to go before the game.
author: Ally D.

description: Perhaps the best burger I have ever had in my life.  Awesome.  Pricey, but not unreasonably so.  Great service as well.
author: Mosey S.

description: Great location next to the ball park, okay service and food, bar mix drink also okay but you are better off with beer.
author: Chris A.

description: Really bland cioppino. Seafood was fresh, although a bit overcooked. Don't bother.
author: Tala D.

description: If you like crabs, they make a mean crab meat salad here.  This is a great place for a lunch break from work, either with a co-worker or by yourself.  I like the little bar section here cuz I can read newspaper while eat lunch w/ no one irritating me w/ pick up lines.  But if you want to taste super-expensive-but-not-so-yummy spring rolls, you can also find them here :(  This is a great place for pre and post-game parties, but it tends to get very crowded.
author: Wendy H.

description:
I think the people who come here before a baseball game have difference experiences than those who just regularly dine in this restaurant for a lunch or dinner. I came here on a weekend for lunch and the food and service was fantastic. Don't come here before a game because my prediction is that you won't get the full Momo's experience.

The Blackened Red Snapper, Chicken Pot Pie, and Philly Cheesesteak were all very tasty and delicious. The Angus Steak w/ sauteed onions and portabello mushrooms was just ok. I wouldn't recommend ordering it since there are plenty other dishes that are better. The calamari appetizer has to be the most tender i've ever had and the egg rolls were great as well. Also, before your meal they give you this carrot cake muffin that is sooo good. it tastes more like a savory dessert than anything, but they gave us extra that we took home. yum!

The servers were nice and friendly. They always refilled our water and asked how our meal was going. An upscale casual place with glasses, tabelcloth settings, and waiters with white button-down shirts, but still casual enough to wear your jeans not feel too stuffy. On a nice sunny day it's nice to eat outside under the umbrella tables. All in all, a great restaurant with great food that hasn't let me down.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Great patio if its nice out. (1 star)

Bad service (had to ask for silverware after the food arrived, had to wait...food sitting on table. friend asked 2 different people for another napkin - never got it, never refilled waters, not friendly.)

Food was only so/so, and extremely expensive for what it was. (grilled chicken cesar salad - flavorless, wilted, $14+)

The bar might be nice to hit pre/post game. I don't know, but I won't be going back.
author: Alexa S.

description:
